text:
Sawaddee ka welcome to a special hot thai kitchen 
series the five colors of thai rice that's right

Thailand has so many different options of rice 
available lots of different colors and textures

and that's what the series is all about this is 
the first of five videos and I'm going to dive

into the different colors of rice including 
some really interesting and healthy options

as well so let's get started with the first 
one so I'm going to start out our series with

the benchmark rice the good old Thai jasmine 
white rice because for most Thai people this

is our staple grain I grew up eating this every 
single day and often three times a day now when

you buy jasmine rice on the back you might 
see it labeled as hom mali rice and hom means

fragrant and mali is Jasmine that's what we 
call it in Thailand now it is famous for its

wonderful floral aroma which you should be able 
to smell right when you open the bag hmm it just

smell really good now the stickiness of fasten'd 
rice is halfway between basmati rice and sushi

rice but what's really lovely about it is its 
soft fluffy tenderness white rice is the best

kind of rice for absorbing sauces and it also 
takes on seasoning a fried rice really well

how do you know that the rice you are buying 
is actually genuine jasmine rice as opposed

to cheaper varieties of rice possibly parading 
in a jasmine rice bag well what you can do is

look for this green logo right here this is a 
Thai government seal that certifies of the rice

inside this bag is one genuine jasmine variety 
and to produce in Thailand now I have to say

that if your bag of rice does not have this label 
it doesn't mean that that's not real jasmine rice

it just means that it hasn't been certified so 
when in doubt you can look for this little logo

and when you cook gas and rice you always want to 
rinse it first a couple of times and know we're

not trying to clean it but we are trying to wash 
off the excess starch which you can actually see

in your rinse water and that will prevent your 
rice from becoming gummy and sticky and as for

how much water to use for one cup of rice I use 
anywhere between one and a quarter cups to one

and a half cups of water and that'll depend on the 
brand of rice and also your preference some people

like softer rice some people like firmer rice so 
it's something you got to try out and if you don't

have a rice cooker you can cook jasmine rice on 
the stovetop in a regular pot very easily and I

have a video all about that I'll put the link 
right up here let's face it the white jasmine

rice gets a 10 on the Pacey scale I mean I can 
literally eat a bowl of plain white jasmine rice

but it doesn't score so high on the healthy scale 
so if you want healthier options stay tuned I got

lots more of that coming up in this series but 
if you want to keep eating white rice and you

want to retain all the nutrients that it's got to 
offer I have one tip for you don't use the pasta

method for cooking the rice and the pasta method 
is exactly what it sounds like you cook the rice

in lots and lots of water and then when it's done 
you drain it like you would pasta now lots of

people use that method because it's nice and easy 
you don't have to measure anything but you will

lose some of the B vitamins that is water-soluble 
along with the boiling water and that concludes

our first episode of the five colors of Thai rice 
series look out for my next video to see what

color we are going to explore next if you've got 
questions about rice get in touch with me Facebook

Twitter Instagram or through my website hot item 
calm and I will see you next time so what he had
